questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10 tablets of paracetamol. He has developed oliguria and LFTs are deranged. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. N-acetylcysteine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the event of paracetamol toxicity, the antidote of choice is N-acetylcysteine, which should be administered as soon as possible to mitigate liver damage and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: In a study involving radiographic evaluations, two physicians independently assessed 100 chest X-rays. They calculated a Kappa statistic of 0.71 to measure inter-rater agreement. What does this Kappa value indicate about the level of agreement between the two doctors? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Substantial

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Kappa statistic is used to measure the degree of agreement between two raters beyond what would be expected by chance. Here's what each value typically indicates about the level of agreement:
  • • A. Slight : A Kappa value from 0.01 to 0.20. This range indicates that there is minimal agreement between the two raters, barely above what would be expected by random chance.
  • • A. Slight
  • • B. Fair: A Kappa value from 0.21 to 0.40. This suggests there is some agreement between the raters, but it remains relatively low.
  • • B. Fair:
  • • C. Moderate: A Kappa value from 0.41 to 0.60. This level indicates a moderate amount of agreement, showing that the raters often agree on their assessments.
  • • C. Moderate:
  • • D. Substantial: A Kappa value from 0.61 to 0.80. This indicates a high level of agreement, suggesting that the raters consistently agree in their assessments most of the time.
  • • D. Substantial:
  • • E. Near Perfect agreement – kappa value from 0.81 to 0.99
  • • E. Near Perfect agreement
  • • F. Perfect agreement – Kappa value – 1.00
  • • F. Perfect agreement
  • • In this case, a Kappa value of 0.71 falls within the "Substantial" category, indicating a strong and consistent level of agreement between the two physicians assessing the chest X-rays. This is generally considered an excellent result in clinical settings, as it shows that both observers have a similar interpretation of the radiographic images, which can greatly improve diagnostic accuracy and patient care.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The Kappa statistic is a reliable tool for assessing the consistency and reliability of diagnostic interpretations between different raters, especially in medical imaging where subjective judgment can vary.
  • ➤ High Kappa values, like 0.71, reinforce the reliability of the assessments and the potential for standardized approaches in clinical practice

questions.text: What will be the duration of below-knee POP cast applied for the following injury?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6-8 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fractures of the metatarsals, including those at the base of the fifth metatarsal, are typically treated with a below-knee plaster cast for a duration of 6-8 weeks to ensure proper healing.
  • ➤ 6-8 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding CORDS? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19

options.label: D
options.text: Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19

questions.correct_answer: B. CORADS-5 is typical of COVID-19
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • CORADS-COVID-19 Reporting and Data System
  • • CO-RADS is a categorical assessment scale used to evaluate pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT scans. Each category reflects the level of suspicion of COVID-19.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CO-RADS-0: This category indicates that the CT examination is insufficient for assessment, not that the lungs are normal, which is a common misunderstanding.
  • • Option A. CO-RADS-0:
  • • Option C. Pleural thickening: While pleural thickening can occur in COVID-19, it is not typical or diagnostic of the disease. COVID-19 primarily affects the parenchyma of the lungs rather than the pleura.
  • • Option C. Pleural thickening:
  • • Option D. Lobar consolidation: Though lobar consolidation may be present in severe cases of COVID-19, it is not typical of the disease, as COVID-19 more frequently presents with peripheral ground-glass opacities.
  • • Option D. Lobar consolidation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ COVID-19 Reporting and Data System (CO-RADS) is a categorical assessment for pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT.

questions.text: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IL-4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inferior turbinate

Its large surface area and vascular mucosa play essential roles in the humidification and warming of inhaled air, contributing to the overall respiratory health and protection against pathogens and particulate matter.

questions.text: Which plasmodium species affects the brain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) P. falciparum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Plasmodium species that affects the brain and can cause cerebral malaria is Plasmodium falciparum.
  • • Among the four major Plasmodium species that cause malaria (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale), only P. falciparum is associated with cerebral malaria.
  • • While all Plasmodium species can cause malaria symptoms like fever, anemia, and splenomegaly, complications like cerebral malaria are caused specifically by P. falciparum.
  • • Pernicious malaria - (due to heavy parasitization)
  • • Pernicious malaria - (due to heavy parasitization)
  • • In cerebral malaria, P. falciparum parasites invade and clog the cerebral blood vessels, leading to brain involvement, hyperpyrexia, coma and paralysis Algid malaria: characterized by cold clammy skin leading to peripheral circulatory failure Septicemic malaria: characterized by high continuous fever with involvement of various organs
  • • In cerebral malaria, P. falciparum parasites invade and clog the cerebral blood vessels, leading to brain involvement, hyperpyrexia, coma and paralysis
  • • Algid malaria: characterized by cold clammy skin leading to peripheral circulatory failure
  • • Septicemic malaria: characterized by high continuous fever with involvement of various organs
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. P. vivax, C. P. malariae, and D. P. ovale: These species can cause uncomplicated malaria but do not typically affect the brain or lead to cerebral malaria.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasmodium falciparum is the only Plasmodium species that can cause cerebral malaria, a potentially life-threatening complication in which the parasites invade and clog the brain's blood vessels.

questions.text: Testosterone production is mainly contributed by?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Leydig cell

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells.
  • • In puberty, the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis plays a major role in regulating testosterone levels and gonadal function. The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which travels down the hypothalamohypophyseal portal system to the anterior pituitary, which secretes luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). LH and FSH are two gonadotropic hormones that travel through the blood and act on receptors in the gonads. LH, in particular, acts on the Leydig cells to increase testosterone production. Testosterone limits its own secretion via negative feedback.
  • • In puberty, the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis plays a major role in regulating testosterone levels and gonadal function.
  • • The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which travels down the hypothalamohypophyseal portal system to the anterior pituitary, which secretes luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
  • • LH and FSH are two gonadotropic hormones that travel through the blood and act on receptors in the gonads.
  • • LH, in particular, acts on the Leydig cells to increase testosterone production. Testosterone limits its own secretion via negative feedback.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Sertoli cells : Incorrect as Sertoli cells are primarily involved in the nourishment and support of developing spermatozoa, not in the production of testosterone.
  • • Option B. Sertoli cells
  • • Option C. Seminiferous tubules : Incorrect because while these structures within the testes are involved in sperm production, the cells directly responsible for testosterone production are the Leydig cells, not the tubules themselves.
  • • Option C. Seminiferous tubules
  • • Option D. Epididymis : Incorrect as the epididymis is involved in the storage, maturation, and transport of sperm cells, not hormone production.
  • • Option D. Epididymis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells in the testes, which are specifically stimulated by luteinizing hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary gland. This hormonal production is crucial for male reproductive and general health.

questions.text: A 45-year-old researcher is keenly interested in understanding the relationship between lung cancer and smoking habits. After conducting an extensive study and analyzing his data, he finds that the attributable risk is 90%. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of this result? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

options.label: B
options.text: 90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

options.label: C
options.text: 90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in smokers if smoking is eliminated

options.label: D
options.text: 10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

questions.correct_answer: A. 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population
  • ➤ Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure
  • ➤ Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population

questions.text: Oil droplet cataract is seen in? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Galactosemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Oil droplet cataract is characteristically seen in galactosemia. This type of cataract presents as a central oil droplet appearance in the lens, which is a distinctive finding in patients with this metabolic disorder. Galactosemia is a genetic condition that affects the body's ability to process the sugar galactose properly, leading to its accumulation in various tissues, including the lens of the eye, resulting in the oil droplet appearance.
  • • central oil droplet
  • • appearance
  • • In galactosemia, early detection and dietary management can help prevent or reduce the severity of cataracts and other complications. The mnemonic to remember this association is that "oil" and "gallons" both start with "gal," linking oil droplet cataract to galactosemia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Myotonic dystrophy : The cataract seen in myotonic dystrophy is typically a Christmas tree cataract , characterized by multi-colored, glittering, needle-shaped crystals within the lens.
  • • Option A. Myotonic dystrophy
  • • Christmas tree cataract
  • • Option C. Wilson's disease : This condition is associated with a sunflower cataract, where deposits of copper cause a characteristic sunburst pattern in the lens.
  • • Option C. Wilson's disease
  • • sunflower cataract,
  • • Option D. Diabetes mellitus : Diabetic patients are more likely to develop snowflake cataracts , which are characterized by flake-like opacities within the lens.
  • • Option D. Diabetes mellitus
  • • snowflake cataracts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oil droplet cataract is a distinctive feature seen in patients with galactosemia, a genetic disorder that impairs the metabolism of galactose, leading to characteristic changes in the lens of the eye.
  • ➤ Oil droplet cataract
  • ➤ galactosemia,
  • ➤ Note – Oil droplet reflex on retinoscopy seen in - Keratoconus
  • ➤ Note – Oil droplet reflex on retinoscopy seen in - Keratoconus

questions.text: A and B in the graph below represent which of the following ions, in terms of permeability for action potential generation: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: A is Na+, B is K+

options.label: B
options.text: A is Na+, B is Ca2+

options.label: C
options.text: A is K+, B is Ca2+

options.label: D
options.text: A is Ca2+, B is K+

questions.correct_answer: A. A is Na+, B is K+
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A is Na+, B is K+

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During an action potential, the initial rapid depolarization is due to an increase in Na+ permeability (represented by A), followed by repolarization due to an increase in K+ permeability (represented by B).

questions.text: A patient presents with infection of the cavernous sinus with involvement of the nerve related on its medial side. To confirm the involvement of the abducent nerve, the patient is asked to look towards: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lateral side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) controls the lateral rectus muscle, which moves the eye laterally. Damage to this nerve results in the inability to move the eye outward, leading to a medial squint (esotropia).
  • ➤ Mnemonic – EOM3 SO4 LR6 (all extraocular muscle are supplied by 3 rd CN except Superior oblique which is supplied by 4 th CN and lateral rectus muscle which is supplied by 6 th cranial nerve)
  • ➤ Mnemonic

Additionally, the program is part of the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karikram (RBSK ), targeting the screening of 30 disorders in children.

  • • Option A. Anemia Mukt Bharat program
  • • Option C. Swachh Bharat Mission : This initiative focuses on cleanliness and sanitation across India but is not related to the School Health program integration.

Educational Objective:

questions.text: 2,3 BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues because:

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains

options.label: C
options.text: Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation

questions.correct_answer: C. Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ 2,3 BPG is formed in RL shunt which has no net ATP production 2,3 BPG has negative charge whereas beta chain of hemoglobin has large negative charges due to amino acids His and Lys. Together they form the salt bridges (see fig) which promote formation of taut conformation and helps in deoxygenation.
  • ➤ 2,3 BPG is formed in RL shunt which has no net ATP production
  • ➤ 2,3 BPG has negative charge whereas beta chain of hemoglobin has large negative charges due to amino acids His and Lys. Together they form the salt bridges (see fig) which promote formation of taut conformation and helps in deoxygenation.
  • ➤ When 2,3 BPG levels gets decreased, it promotes relaxed confirmation of Hb resulting in oxygen loading.
  • ➤ When 2,3 BPG levels gets decreased, it promotes relaxed confirmation of Hb resulting in oxygen loading.

questions.text: Which of these hormones have intracellular receptors? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thyroxine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thyroxine acts by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis. This distinguishes it from hormones like epinephrine, glucagon, and parathormone, which bind to receptors on the cell membrane.

questions.text: Identify the part of the cochlear implant marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Grounding electrode

Educational Objective:

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron

options.label: C
options.text: Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool

options.label: D
options.text: Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.correct_answer: A. Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Decerebrate rigidity is the rigid extension of all the limbs due to decerebration. This type of rigidity is well pronounced in the extensor muscles. The term decerebrate rigidity was coined by Sherrington in 1897.
  • • Reason for decerebrate rigidity:
  • • Reason for decerebrate rigidity:
  • • Release of the centers, situated below the section, from higher inhibitory controls. The inhibitory area is 4S. It is situated in the motor cortex of cerebrum, just anterior to area 4 and behind area 6. In this area, Betz cells are absent. From here, the fibers are projected to spinal cord via reticular formation. So, in decerebration the discharge from neurons of area 4S cannot reach spinal motor neurons. This leads to exaggeration of spinal motor neurons resulting in rigidity. Decerebrate rigidity is also produced by stopping the blood flow to the forebrain. It is done by occlusion of the common carotid artery and the basilar artery at the center of the pons.
  • • Release of the centers, situated below the section, from higher inhibitory controls. The inhibitory area is 4S. It is situated in the motor cortex of cerebrum, just anterior to area 4 and behind area 6. In this area, Betz cells are absent.
  • • From here, the fibers are projected to spinal cord via reticular formation. So, in decerebration the discharge from neurons of area 4S cannot reach spinal motor neurons. This leads to exaggeration of spinal motor neurons resulting in rigidity.
  • • Decerebrate rigidity is also produced by stopping the blood flow to the forebrain. It is done by occlusion of the common carotid artery and the basilar artery at the center of the pons.
  • • Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by
  • • γ motor neuron discharge rate increased. Motor neuron pool excitability increased. Decerebration produces no phenomenon similar to spinal shock. Antigravity extensor muscles are involved in decerebrate injury
  • • γ motor neuron discharge rate increased.
  • • Motor neuron pool excitability increased.
  • • Decerebration produces no phenomenon similar to spinal shock.
  • • Antigravity extensor muscles are involved in decerebrate injury
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron : Correct as part of the characterization of decerebrate rigidity. The increased discharge rate of the γ efferent neurons enhances the muscle spindle responses, contributing to increased muscle tone.
  • • Option B. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron
  • • Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool : Correct, this increased excitability leads to the hyperactivity of motor neurons, particularly those controlling the extensor muscles.
  • • Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
  • • Option D. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock : Correct, unlike spinal shock, which involves a temporary reduction or loss of reflex activity below the level of a spinal cord injury, decerebration does not produce a similar transient reduction in reflexes.
  • • Option D. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by an increase in extensor muscle tone due to enhanced activity of the γ motor neurons and increased excitability of the motor neuron pool, without inducing effects similar to spinal shock. Rigidity does not occur in all muscles of the body but is more pronounced in antigravity extensor muscles.

Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) commonly and type 2 (HSV-2) rarely are responsible for its occurrence

  • • Causative agent:

  • • Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: Pearly white, wart-like umbilicated papules seen due to infection by Pox virus .

Educational Objective:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The marked structure C is the medial epicondyle. The Ulnar nerve passes from behind the epicondyle. Injury to the ulnar nerve at this area causes ulnar claw hand i.e., the extension of IP joints of 4 th and 5 th fingers; along with weakness in grip of the hand.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treatment with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crigler Najjar type 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crigler-Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that responds to phenobarbital, distinguishing it from other forms of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: An elderly woman reports difficulty in buttoning her shirt and increased clumsiness in performing daily activities. On examination, the clinician asked her to make an 'O' using her thumb and index finger, which she was unable to do. Which of the following muscles is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Flexor pollicis longus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome affects the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus muscles, leading to difficulty in forming an 'O' with the thumb and index finger due to impaired flexion.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presenting at less than 34 weeks of gestation displays signs of mild to moderate anemia. Under the "Anemia Mukh Bharat" initiative, which therapeutic approach would be the most appropriate? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: 3 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets, taken OD

options.label: B
options.text: IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets

options.label: C
options.text: 2 iron and folic acid tablets OD + IV iron sucrose

questions.correct_answer: B. IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anemia Mukt Bharat (2018)
  • ➤ Anemia Mukt Bharat (2018)
  • ➤ Aim: Reduce anemia by 3% per year
  • ➤ 6 x 6 x 6 strategy

questions.text: Which of the following is the topical local anesthetic used in cataract surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Proparacaine 0.5%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proparacaine 0.5% is the preferred topical anesthetic for cataract surgery due to its rapid onset, appropriate duration of action, and minimal systemic absorption.

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is caused by deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngismus stridulus is a manifestation of severe rickets caused by vitamin D deficiency, resulting in hypocalcemia and laryngeal muscle spasms.

questions.text: Patient develops severe migratory joint pain after an attack of acute rheumatic fever. How will you manage this patient? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aspirin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The correct answer is Aspirin. Acute rheumatic fever commonly presents with migratory polyarthritis , which is characterized by severe joint pain that moves from one joint to another.
  • • migratory polyarthritis
  • • The treatment of choice for this arthritis is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), with aspirin being the most effective and commonly used. Aspirin helps to reduce inflammation and pain associated with the arthritis of acute rheumatic fever.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Furosemide: This is a diuretic and is not used for the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever. It may be used in cases of heart failure associated with rheumatic carditis.
  • • Option A. Furosemide:
  • • Option B. Digoxin: This is a cardiac glycoside used in heart failure and atrial fibrillation. It is not used for managing arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.
  • • Option B. Digoxin:
  • • Option D. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication and has no role in the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.
  • • Option D. Amiodarone:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary treatment for severe migratory joint pain (arthritis) in acute rheumatic fever is the use of NSAIDs, with aspirin being the drug of choice due to its effectiveness in reducing inflammation and pain.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)? ( INICET Nov 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment

options.label: B
options.text: Prevalence is 7 -10 percent in general population

questions.correct_answer: C. Depression is a common comorbidity
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Depression is a common comorbidity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ OCD is characterized by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3% and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.
  • ➤ 2-3%
  • ➤ Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing
  • ➤ Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 95-97.

questions.text: What is the ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3:1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.
  • ➤ T cells to B cells
  • ➤ 3:1.
  • ➤ Ratio of CD4 to CD8 T-cells is 2:1.
  • ➤ CD4 to CD8 T-cells is 2:1.

questions.explanation:
Ans.

questions.text: A surgically resected specimen of an ovarian mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mature cystic teratoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are characterized by the presence of multiple tissue types such as hair, sebaceous material, and sometimes teeth or bone within a cystic ovarian mass.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg

questions.text: A patient is presenting with a staggering gait and nystagmus (Rhomberg sign +ve) after a road traffic accident. Which lobe of cerebellum is affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Flocculonodular

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is crucial for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Damage to this area can lead to symptoms such as a staggering gait, nystagmus, and balance issues, as seen in the case of cerebellar ataxia following trauma.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is due to which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Peroxisomes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zellweger syndrome is caused by a defect in peroxisomes, leading to the accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids and branched-chain fatty acids, which are not properly metabolized due to the lack of functional peroxisomes.

questions.text: The following graph is most likely to be seen in: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Non-competitive inhibition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Features of Non-competitive Inhibition
  • ➤ Features of Non-competitive Inhibition
  • ➤ The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, other than the substrate binding site and the inhibitor has no structural resemblance to substrate and hence, excess substrate does not abolish the inhibition. The inhibitor combines with the enzymes by a covalent bond, which makes the reaction irreversible. The velocity (Vmax) is reduced and the Km value is not changed , because the remaining enzyme molecules have the same affinity for the substrate.
  • ➤ The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, other than the substrate binding site and the inhibitor has no structural resemblance to substrate and hence, excess substrate does not abolish the inhibition.
  • ➤ The inhibitor combines with the enzymes by a covalent bond, which makes the reaction irreversible.
  • ➤ The velocity (Vmax) is reduced and the Km value is not changed , because the remaining enzyme molecules have the same affinity for the substrate.
  • ➤ velocity (Vmax) is reduced
  • ➤ Km value is not changed
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 80-81
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 80-81

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia. She was given folate 5mg and the blood picture improved. However, the neurologic manifestations were aggravated. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency

options.label: C
options.text: Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS

options.label: D
options.text: Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.correct_answer: D. Folate therapy using the B12 stores
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Folate therapy using the B12 stores

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Folic acid doses over 1 mg may cause aggravation of vitamin B12 deficiency and may precipitate nerve damage .
  • ➤ Folic acid doses over 1 mg may cause aggravation of vitamin B12 deficiency and may precipitate nerve damage
  • ➤ The most likely cause is folate therapy which used up the B12 stores, aggravating the symptoms.
  • ➤ Administration of folic acid for patients with macrocytic anemia can partially reverse the hematologic abnormalities associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. However, the neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are not treated by folic acid.
  • ➤ However, the neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are not treated by folic acid.
